Award.AwardTitle: High Energy Routes to Strained Molecules and Reactive Intermediates
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Richard Johnson and his students at the University of New Hampshire Department of Chemistry will investigate the chemistry of highly energetic intermediates, which are generated either by protonation in superacids, hydrogen atom addition, thermolysis or electron transfer. One important goal is to explore the cationic and free-radical isomerization of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons. These are substances of broad importance across science - from interstellar chemistry to materials for molecular electronics. This project includes a high level of synergy between theory and experiment. The proposed research represents an intellectually rich and diverse series of computational and experimental experiences, which will serve as effective training for graduate and undergraduate students at the University of New Hampshire, including women and minorities. Outreach activities will focus on the development of new undergraduate laboratory experiments which are based on NSF-funded research across the field of chemistry.

The proposed research continues previous NSF-funded studies. The major focus will be on rearrangements, cyclizations and coupling reactions of aromatic compounds. Proposed superacid-catalyzed chemistry will utilize a microwave reactor to extend the range of cationic chemistry to include new higher energy processes. Building on recent group discoveries, which include both superacid and free-radical catalyzed skeletal isomerizations of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, the principal investigator and his students will combine theory and experiment to seek mechanistic understanding of these reactions. One important goal is to demonstrate that hydrogen atoms are universal catalysts in high temperature chemistry, just as the proton catalyzes reactions in solution. A second major emphasis will be on methodology development and new applications of the electron transfer model for polar bimolecular reactions which was developed at the University of New Hampshire. This model treats all polar bimolecular reactions as single electron transfer processes, using spin density maps to successfully predict regiochemistry and stereochemistry in a broad array of chemical reactions.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project used a combination of experimental and computational methods to investigate organic chemical reactions which involve novel high-energy reactive intermediates.  Our main focus has been on rearrangements and cyclizations of aromatic compounds (arenes) and other conjugated structures,  which result from protonation to give positively charged carbocation intermediates. Arenes undergo a complex collection of acid catalyzed rearrangements, which transpose substituents and ring carbons, in addition to cyclization reactions. This work required us to develop robust and safe methods for studying high temperature reactions in superacids using a chemical microwave reactor. As this project concludes, the ensemble of our computational and experimental research supports four distinct mechanisms for acid-catalyzed arene rearrangements:  1,2-Shift mechanisms are most common. These have been known for over 100 years but the factors controlling product selectivity was poorly understood. Our computations support a complex network of competing processes among ipso arenium ions, which arise from protonation at the site of a substituent or ring fusion. We have shown that the observed reaction products best correlate with product carbocation stability; this supports thermodynamic control. As one example,  acid-catalyzed rearrangements of all six isomers of quaterphenyl (Ph-Ph-Ph-Ph) yield the m,p'-isomer upon heating with trifluoromethanesulfonic acid. After much effort, we were able to show that alkyl ring pirouettes, passing through spirocyclic intermediates, explain the unidirectional skeletal rearrangement of anthracene to phenanthrene.  This requires an ionic reduction or oxidation at each end of the reaction scheme. Aryl ring pirouettes explain earlier reports of automerization in phenanthrene, as well as interconversions among four-ring arenes studied by us. Benz[a]anthracene and [4]helicene both connect  to chrysene through a common spirocyclic intermediate. Tetracene eschews this mechanism because of a high barrier for aryl pirouette.  Our results support ionic reduction (protonation, then hydride transfer), followed by cleavage of one ring to a benzyl cation intermediate. 

Among other carbocation mechanisms, we have shown that the classic Scholl synthesis of perylene from naphthalene, first reported in 1910, proceeds through the rapid interconversion of 1,1'-binaphthyl with 2,2'-binaphthyl and only slowly gives cyclization to perylene.   We also used computations to study a biomimetic cyclization route to the natural product griffipavixanthone.  This is explained by a complex cascade of carbocation processes.  An efficient synthesis of the [3]triangulene ring system was achieved by cascade benzyl cation cyclization to give the fluorescent and very stable 4,8,12-trihydrotriangulenium cation,  which was easily observed by nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy. Nucleophilic quenching yielded suitable precursors to [3]triangulene,  which was generated in the solution phase for the first time. Significant progress was made towards an efficient synthesis of the next homolog [4]triangulene.   Synthetic routes to polycyclic fluorene derivatives were developed by cyclization of diarylmethyl carbocations.  DFT computations easily predicted the regiochemistry of these cyclizations.

Computations were used to rationalize point to axial chirality transfer in the first atropselective synthesis of rugulotrosin, a dimeric tetrahydroxanthone natural product.  Our predictions for thermal biaryl rotational barriers helped to explain the formation of liquid crystalline oligopyrenes.

In earlier research, we had developed the concept of dehydropericyclic reactions, which can be envisioned by systematic dehydrogenation of ordinary pericyclic reactions.  Further progress was made in the study of two novel dehydropericyclic reactions, which were first discovered in our group with earlier NSF support.  These reactions challenge the limits of orbital symmetrycontrol.  We showed earlier that simple acyclic enynes undergo photochemical transposition of the methylene carbon. Our computations located an excited state conical intersection, which appears to connect with 1,2-cyclobutadiene on the ground state surface This is a remarkable hydrocarbon. Analysis of this structure supports a highly unusual type of carbon-carbon bonding. As we posited  earlier, a low barrier to thermal ring opening explains the enyne photorearrangement.  In 1997, our group co-discovered the thermal alkyne+ 1,3-diyne [2+4] cycloaddition to give ortho-benzynes,  a reaction now widely used by synthetic chemists. For tethered yne +diyne structures, our computations predict a slight enthalpic advantage for concerted reaction but free energies favor a stepwise cycloaddition process. In another project, dehydropericyclic closure  of Z,Z-3,5-octadiene-1,7-diynes to stable but antiaromatic benzocyclobutadienes was shown by computation to proceed by two successive electrocyclic reactions, both with low barriers.

The broader scientific impact of this project has been to expand fundamental knowledge of structure,  molecular rearrangements,  pericyclic reactions and the synergistic role of computational models in guiding experiments. Some extraordinary new structures have been synthesized,  many as reactive intermediates.  This project served as effective training for graduate and undergraduate students at the University of New Hampshire, including women and minorities.  The Principal Investigator provided contributions to the scientific community through extensive service with NSF, training students and faculty in computational chemistry during the Covid-lockdown and by co-chairing the 2019 Physical Organic Gordon Conference.

 


Last Modified: 06/25/2021
Modified by: Arthur Greenberg
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project used a combination of experimental and computational methods to investigate organic chemical reactions which involve novel high-energy reactive intermediates. Our main focus has been on rearrangements and cyclizations of aromatic compounds (arenes) and other conjugated structures, which result from protonation to give positively charged carbocation intermediates. Arenes undergo a complex collection of acid catalyzed rearrangements, which transpose substituents and ring carbons, in addition to cyclization reactions. This work required us to develop robust and safe methods for studying high temperature reactions in superacids using a chemical microwave reactor. As this project concludes, the ensemble of our computational and experimental research supports four distinct mechanisms for acid-catalyzed arene rearrangements: 1,2-Shift mechanisms are most common. These have been known for over 100 years but the factors controlling product selectivity was poorly understood. Our computations support a complex network of competing processes among ipso arenium ions, which arise from protonation at the site of a substituent or ring fusion. We have shown that the observed reaction products best correlate with product carbocation stability; this supports thermodynamic control. As one example, acid-catalyzed rearrangements of all six isomers of quaterphenyl (Ph-Ph-Ph-Ph) yield the m,p'-isomer upon heating with trifluoromethanesulfonic acid. After much effort, we were able to show that alkyl ring pirouettes, passing through spirocyclic intermediates, explain the unidirectional skeletal rearrangement of anthracene to phenanthrene. Benz[a]anthracene and [4]helicene both connect to chrysene through a common spirocyclic intermediate. Tetracene eschews this mechanism because of a high barrier for aryl pirouette. Our results support ionic reduction (protonation, then hydride transfer), followed by cleavage of one ring to a benzyl cation intermediate. We also used computations to study a biomimetic cyclization route to the natural product griffipavixanthone. This is explained by a complex cascade of carbocation processes. Our computations located an excited state conical intersection, which appears to connect with 1,2-cyclobutadiene on the ground state surface This is a remarkable hydrocarbon. Analysis of this structure supports a highly unusual type of carbon-carbon bonding. As we posited earlier, a low barrier to thermal ring opening explains the enyne photorearrangement. In 1997, our group co-discovered the thermal alkyne+ 1,3-diyne [2+4] cycloaddition to give ortho-benzynes, a reaction now widely used by synthetic chemists. For tethered yne +diyne structures, our computations predict a slight enthalpic advantage for concerted reaction but free energies favor a stepwise cycloaddition process. In another project, dehydropericyclic closure of Z,Z-3,5-octadiene-1,7-diynes to stable but antiaromatic benzocyclobutadienes was shown by computation to proceed by two successive electrocyclic reactions, both with low barriers. The broader scientific impact of this project has been to expand fundamental knowledge of structure, molecular rearrangements, pericyclic reactions and the synergistic role of computational models in guiding experiments. Some extraordinary new structures have been synthesized, many as reactive intermediates. This project served as effective training for graduate and undergraduate students at the University of New Hampshire, including women and minorities. The Principal Investigator provided contributions to the scientific community through extensive service with NSF, training students and faculty in computational chemistry during the Covid-lockdown and by co-chairing the 2019 Physical Organic Gordon Conference.
